He used the profit to pay school fees, buy a refrigerator, and pay household expenses.  He has paid back all his loans successfully. He will use this loan to buy more beauty salon equipment.  He dreams of buying a plot of land.

Lordvick will share this loan with his loan group "Up To Date" which has seven members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more salon equipment.

loans.name: Sodik

texts.en:
Sodik is a hardworking man. He is 35 years old, married, and has two children. He owns a bookstore, which is based in a room in the local market. Here he offers school supplies: college notebooks, lined notebooks, double lined notebooks, pens, and staplers. He is a newcomer to this business. He began his business 5 months ago. 
To improve business, he is borrowing the amount of 7,500 TJS from Imon International organization to buy office supplies, such as books, notebooks, and pens, for increasing working capital. He’s hopeful of the possibility of expanding his business before long.

loans.use: To buy office supplies, such as books, notebooks and pens, for increasing working capital

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 47-year-old Zainab from Torkpoi town Bo. She is married with 9 children. Seven of her children are currently attending school. She began this business because she wants to create income to support her children.

Zainab runs a general stock business; she sells soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets. She has been running this business for 15 years. She works ten hour days throughout the week.  Zainab says that sometimes business is very difficult.

Zainab has requested a loan in order to purchase soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her enterprise more than ever. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, bread, biscuit and sweet for resale.

loans.name: Nut

texts.en:
Nut is 43 years old, married, and a farmer in the Prey Chhor district, Kampong Cham province. She has four dependent children at various ages. She has been involved in the farming business for more than 20 years and also sells meat or vegetables door-to-door around the village for additional income. Her husband, who is also a farmer, is now dedicated to a fishing business during the high-water season.

Due to the lack of capital to invest in the purchase of fishing materials, Nut is requesting a loan of KHR 1,000,000 from HKL, a long-standing Kiva partner, to buy a boat and fishing nets for her husband to manage his business. This loan will allow her husband to continue with his fishing activities and make additional income to secure their family.

loans.use: to buy a boat and fishing nets for her husband to manage his fishing business.

loans.name: L'oeil De Dieu (1) Group

texts.en: Mireille is one of the members of the group L’Oeil de Dieu (1). The group consists of 10 female micro-entrepreneurs from Brazzaville, Congo. Mireille is a single mother of two children, ages 12 and 23 years old. She is very excited to be receiving her first loan from HOPE Congo. She has had her business for around six years. Her business consists primarily of selling small pastries and local juices. With this next loan, she will be able to buy more of the ingredients she needs to make her juice and pastries. By buying in bulk, she will be able to reduce her prices, giving her a competitive advantage in her bustling market. With her future profits, Mireille hopes to be able to one day begin importing goods to further diversity her inventory and maybe one day build a house for her family. She thanks you all for your support!!!

loans.use: to pay for ingredients to make pastries and local juice

loans.name: Massah

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 38-year-old Massah from Moribatown Bo. She is married with three children between the ages of 4 and 13 years old. Two of her children are currently attending school. 

Massah runs a retail shop where she sells rice, pepper and cooking seasonings. She has been running this business for 12 years. She works at the business 10 hours per day throughout the week.  Massah says that sometimes business is very difficult.

Massah has requested a loan in order to purchase cooking seasonings, rice and palm oil for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to repay her loan and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her enterprise more than ever. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking seasonings, rice and palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Sarkis

texts.en:
Sarkis, 69, is from the Lagodekhi district, East Georgia. He lives with his wife and grown son. Sarkis and his wife Naili get retirement pensions. The family runs an agricultural business and breeds two milk cows and a calf. The milk is used in cheese production. In addition, Sarkis grows maize, cabbages and peanuts to sell.

In order to generate income for the family's wellbeing, Sarkis will start a trading business with fruits and vegetables in his district but he needs a van for making deliveries. With the received loan, Sarkis will pay for the van and start selling fresh products. He will also sell his harvest in season and earn an income.

Sarkis is a very hardworking man, with a great desire to ensure that his family members have proper living conditions. He awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase a van to use in his trading business

loans.name: Yeabu

texts.en:
Meet 47-year-old Yeabu from Moribatown Bo in Sierra Leone. She is married with four children.  Two of her children are going to school.  In 2005, Yeabu established her plastic slippers business. She began her business because she needed to generate income to take care of herself and her family. She works at the business every day from morning to night.  She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and slow purchasing power.

Yeabu requires a loan in order to purchase a variety of slippers. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, Yeabu plans to see her business grow to a higher level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of slippers.

loans.name: Tiro Group

texts.en:
Tatu, who is in her late 20s, is single with two children. One of her children goes to school and the other one is still small. She has been a food vendor for two months now.  She works from 8:00 am to 2:00 pm daily and is able to make a very small monthly profit.

This will be Tatu's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She wants to use it to buy more food stock to sell to more people. She dreams of owing a hotel.

Tatu will share this loan with her loan group "Tiro", which has seven members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan

loans.use: to buy more food stock to sell

loans.name: Kou

texts.en: Kou is 38 years old and lives in Gardnersville, Liberia, which is one of the most populated areas in Montserrado County. She is married with two children aged 19 and 21 years old--only one lives at home and is in school. For seven years now, she has been selling used clothes in the local market. She started this business with money given to her by her mother and learned this trade from her. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. She hopes to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Yeabu

texts.en:
Meet 44-year-old Memuna from Moribatown Bo in Sierra Leone. She is married with three children. Her children are going to school. In 2005, Memuna established her ground nut business. She began her business because she needs to generate income to take care of herself and her family. She works at the business every day from morning to night. She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and transportation.
Memuna requires a loan in order to purchase ground nuts, beans, and pepper. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and repay her loan. In the future, Memuna plans to get her business to her higher level. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase ground nuts, beans, and pepper.

loans.name: Chanthy

texts.en:
Chanthy is 44 years old and married with three children. She lives with her spouse and children in her own home located in Kampong Cham province, where she manages rice farming on a few plots of farmland for the family’s sustenance and for sales. She has learned this business from older people and her parents, who transferred it to her in the past 20 years.
As she needs to improve her current business, she has applied for a loan in the amount of KHR 1,200,000 to buy enough farm supplies such as gasoline, fertilizers, and pesticides to ensure a good growth of her rice. In the future, she plans to expand her area for farming and produce a high production, which she sells to local retailers for a good profit.

loans.use: to buy enough farm supplies such as gasoline, fertilizers, and pesticides to ensure a good growth of her rice.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 50-year-old Fatmata from Kandeh town in Sierra Leone. She is married with four children between the ages of 15 and 30. Three of her children are currently attending school. In 1995, Fatmata established her fish business. She began her business because she wants to contribute to taking care of her children. She works at the business eight hours per day and six days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is poor roads.  
Fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase more fish for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and pay her children's school fees. In the future, Fatmata plans to expand her business even more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is 27 years old, and he is married. Ali now lives in the Absheron region with his wife and child. His wife is a housewife, and she educates their junior son. He has been in the tailor business for two years. Ali sews suits, pants, shirts, jackets, and other clothing for men.
Recently, his equipment broke, and he hasn't been able to work. He applied for a loan in the amount of 1000AZN. With this loan, he will repair his equipment and will to continue work. Also, he will buy an iron and an ironing board. Thus, his monthly income will resume.
He is thankful to Kiva and the Komak organization for the aid. Ali wants to recruit a few assistants in the future.

loans.use: to repair his equipment

loans.name: Goretti

texts.en:
Gorretti is a married woman, aged forty-eight years old with seven children of whom three attend different schools. She also lives in a rural area of Masaka district with her family and fifteen other orphans whom she takes care of. She is a farmer who deals in an agricultural business where she grows pineapples, passion fruit and watermelon.

She works six days a week and 12 hours per day and she also owns a retail shop which supplements her income.  She has been in the agricultural business since 2005 and she started the business to earn a living and get money for school fees.

She acquired this loan to buy pesticides and manure for her plantations. She says her clients are traders from Kyotera and Kampala. Her future hopes are to educate the children she is taking care of and to be the leading supplier of agricultural products in her area.

Her problem is the unpredictable weather such as a long drought and she describes herself as a hardworking woman and thanks lenders for the good work.

loans.use: To buy pesticides and manure

loans.name: Abduhalim

texts.ru: Пятидесяти пятилетний Абдухалим имеет большую семью, с которой проживает в городе Куляб. У него жена, пятеро сыновей, трое невесток и шесть внуков. Все они живут в одном большом доме. Четверо сыновей Абдухалима занимаются торговлей в городе Душанбе, а один сын находится на заработках за пределами страны. Абдухалим как глава семьи всегда заботится о благополучии семьи. Сейчас он собирается начать собственный бизнес вместе с одним сыном. Абдухалим на свои сбережения купил торговую точку на рынке города и хочет на сумму от кредита закупить запасные части автомашин и начать свой бизнес. Абдухалим нуждается в кредите в размере 2500 долларов США для закупа товара. Он ждет поддержки с Вашей стороны.
texts.en:
55 year old Abduhalim has a big family with which he lives in the city of Kulyab. He has a wife, five sons, three daughters-in-law and six grandchildren. They all live in one big house. Four of Abduhalim's sons work in retail in the city of Dushanbe, and one son works abroad. Abduhalim as the head of the family has always cared for its welfare. 

Now he plans to start his own business together with one of his sons. Abduhalim has bought a stall space at the city's market with his own savings and he wants to use the money from the loan to buy spare car parts and start his own business. Abduhalim needs a loan of $2500 to buy products. He awaits your help.

loans.use: To buy spare car parts

loans.name: Brahima

texts.fr:
Né  en 1980 à YOPOUGON  en Côte D’IVOIRE, BRAHIMA  réside à DEFINA (Sous-préfecture de Garalo,  3ème Région administrative du Mali) avec ses 3 enfants et sa femme dans une famille traditionnelle.
 Mr BRAHIMA s’est vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat vente d’articles divers de boutique (sucre, thé, savons, bus cuit, huile végétale, lait, etc.).  Il est très sollicité à DEFINA et surtout le jour de foire. 
Fort de ses 10 années d’expériences dans le domaine, il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  quatrième prêt, après avoir remboursé les prêts précédents. 
BRAHIMA compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des articles de boutique (sucre, thé, savons, biscuit, huile de cuisine, lait en poudre, cigarettes, conserves et pâte alimentaires). Il s’approvisionne chez les grossistes à Bougouni et souvent à BAMAKO. Il effectue ses ventes au comptant et quelques fois à crédit  à une clientèle mixte.
BRAHIMA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 55.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
Born in 1980 in Yopougon in Côte d'Ivoire, Brahima lives in Defina (in the Garolo sub-prefecture, third administrative region of Mali) with his three children and wife in a traditional family.

Mr Brahima soon became interested in income-generating activities, in particular the retail sales of general store goods (sugar, tea, soap, biscuits, vegetable oil, milk, etc.). He is very much in demand in Defina, particularly on market days.

With over 10 years of field experience, he collaborates with Soro Yiriwaso to increase his working capital and satisfy an increasing number of customers. He is now on his fourth credit loan, having repaid all previous loans.

Brahima will use the loan to buy general store items (sugar, tea  soap, biscuits, cooking oil, powdered milk, cigarettes, canned food and cheese). He resupplies with wholesalers in Bougouni and often in Bamako. He sells for cash and sometimes on credit to a mixed clientele.

Brahima hopes to achieve an average monthly profit of 55,000 CFA francs that will be used to support the family, repay the loan and for reinvestment in the business.

loans.use: buy general store goods

loans.name: Esmeralda Del Carmen

texts.es: Esmeralda vive en casa propia con su esposo, sus 7 hijos y un nieto, ella se dedica a la compra y venta de chatarra como: aluminio, cobre, bronce,   plástico, hierro, etc. desde hace varios años, comercializa sus ventas en su lugar de residencia, con lo que obtiene de sus ganancias, con la ayuda de su esposo y de sus dos hijas mayores logran cubrir algunos gastos de su hogar, doña esmeralda esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de mas chatarra y vidrio, y así poder seguir con su trabajo y obtener mejores ganancias para tener una mejor estabilidad económica con su familia.
texts.en: Esmeralda lives in her own house with her husband, seven children and one grandson.  She buys and sells scrap metal such as aluminum, copper, bronze, iron, etc. and also plastic.  For a few years now, she has sold these products from her home with the help of her husband and her two oldest children.  With the money she earns they manage to cover some of the household expenses.  Esmeralda is asking for a credit to buy more scrap metal and glass, so she can continue working and improve her income which would bring more economic stability to her family.

loans.use: to buy more scrap aluminum, copper, bronze, iron, etc and plastic and glass.

loans.name: Gbenonkpo Group

texts.fr: GBENONKPO est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui vivent dans le même quartier. La représente du groupe, nommée Ginette (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 30 ans. Ginette n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Ginette ne vit plus avec son mari, mais est mère de trois enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et deux restent à sa charge. Ginette vit avec ses enfants. Grâce aux revenus que lui génère son activité, Ginette arrive à nourrir sa famille. Depuis une dizaine d'année, Ginette mène comme activité la vente de plastiques et de sachets dans sa région. De façon secondaire, Ginette vend des fruits. Ginette achète ses produits dans une ville du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Ginette s’associe aux autres membres du groupe GBENONKPO pour solliciter un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Gbenonkpo is a group of three persons from the same neighborhood. The group representative is named Ginette (the one raising her hand on the photo) and is 30 years old. 

Ginette has not attended school. She no longer lives with her husband, and is the mother of three children. All children attend (or have attended) school and two of them remain under her care. Ginette lives with her children. 

With the money generated by her activity, Ginette is able to feed her family. For over ten years Ginette has been running a business selling plastic items and plastic bags in her area. As an additional activity she also sells fruit.

Ginette buys her products in one of Benin's cities. To bolster her business, she joins the other members of the Gbenonkpo group in seeking a third loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: buy plastic items and plastic bags

loans.name: Ankato Allama Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  ANKATO ALLAMA  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  31ans, 3 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles monogamiques à KOLONDIEBA, une des Sous-préfecture de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités à tout moment. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt avec l’institution.
Mme   SARATA (1ère à gauche sur la photo) compte acheter avec son prêt des condiments pour ensuite les revendre à Zantoumala et en famille. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15 500FCFA.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the Ankato Allama group are married women who on average are 31 years old with three children, all living in monogamous families in Kolondiéba, a sub-prefecture of the third administrative region of Mali.

They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution so they can carry out their activities at any time of year. They are on their fourth loan with the institution.

Ms. Sarata (first on the left in the photo) plans to use the loan to buy condiments for resale in Zantoumala and within her family.

She expects to achieve an average monthly profit of 15,500 CFA francs. These profits will enable her to repay her loan and also to help her husband with daily expenditures.

loans.use: buy condiments

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Né en 1972 à FAKOLA -Ville, (3ème Région administrative du Mali), BOUBACAR  y réside avec son enfant et sa femme dans une famille traditionnelle chez ses parents.
 Mr BOUBACAR s’est vite intéressé à la couture après avoir quitté l’école prématurément. Aujourd’hui il dispose d’un atelier de couture combiné avec un étalage de mercerie au bord de la route dans leur concession  où il coud et vend ses articles. Il est très sollicité dans la ville  et surtout le jour de foire. 
Fort de ses 6 années d’expériences dans le domaine, il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  deuxième prêt. 
BOUBACAR compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des matériels de couture (mercerie) et  tissus. Il s’approvisionne chez les grossistes à BAMAKO et en Côte D’IVOIRE. Il effectue ses ventes au comptant et quelques fois à crédit  à une clientèle mixte.
BOUBACAR espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
Born in 1972 in Fakola City (third administrative region of Mali), Boubacar resides with his wife and child in a traditional family along with his parents.

Mr Boubacar became interested in sewing soon after he left school prematurely. Today he has a combination sewing workshop and haberdashery store along the road at his concession, where he sews and sells his products. He is very much in demand in the city and especially on market days.

With six years' experience in the field, he collaborates with Soro Yiriwaso to increase his working capital and satisfy an increasing number of customers. He is on his second loan.

Boubacar intends to use the loan to buy sewing materials (haberdashery items) and fabrics. He buys from wholesalers in Bamako and from Cote d'Ivoire. He sells for cash and sometimes on credit to a mixed clientele.

Boubacar hopes to make monthly profits of 100,000 CFA francs that will be used to support the family, repay the loan and for reinvestment in the business.

loans.use: Purchase sewing materials (haberdashery items), fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy solar lamps that they will sell in their communities

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen lives and works outside of Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. Originally dominated by English settlers in the early 20th century, the region’s farmland was redistributed after independence. This left Trans-Nzoia, one of Kenya’s most cosmopolitan areas, with individuals from a variety of linguistic and ethnic groups living in close proximity. 

The lush soil of the region ensures that farmers can grow a variety of crops, including maize, sunflower, sugar cane, millet, and beans. Kitale is located near Mount Elgon, East Africa's oldest and largest solitary extinct volcano, whose substantial forest cover makes Kitale a high-potential beekeeping region. 

Stephen is married and has five children. Him and his wife both farm and are currently growing maize and tending to livestock. Stephen is excited to start beekeeping because it is a low-labour activity that will let him focus on his farming. 

This is Stephen’s first loan, and he plans to use the income from his beehives for his family’s development.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    DANAYA est constitué de 7 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de34 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  NIEBALA de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 3éme prêt. Les 2 précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  de grains à l’image de SIATA BOUGOU qui est la 1ére femme de la gauche vers la droite  dans la photo. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 1,5 tonne de maïs avec les paysans producteurs. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The Danaya Group is made up of 7 married women, who have an average age of 34 years and an average of 4 children.  They live in traditional extended families in the Niebala area of Bougouni town.   They know one another through family, business and local ties.  The women joined the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso, in order to strengthen their financial position and improve their businesses.  This will be their third loan with the organisation, the previous two loans have been fully repaid.  

This group of women all buy and sell grain, as does Siata Bougou (the woman standing on the far left of the photo).  Siata Bougou will use her loan to buy 1.5 tonnes of maize from small producers.  She sells her product from home and at the market.  Her customers are usually women and she sells to them for cash and on credit.  She expects to earn a monthly average of 25,000 francs CFA and she will use her earnings to repay the loan and invest in her business.

loans.use: to buy cereal grains.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
Tomas y su esposa son productores de leche la cual vende a una de las empresas recolectoras de la ciudsad de La Paz;  vive en casa propia, tienen dos hijos, los cuales están en edad escolar, en la comunidad Irama Belén del municipio de Achacachi, a dos horas y media de viaje de la ciudad de La Paz, cuenta con pocas cabezas de ganado  las cuales le proporcionan leche.

El crédito lo requiere para compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar su producción de leche y sus ingresos para su familia.

El sueño de Tomas es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado, aumentando la producción  de leche en su comunidad.

Es la primera vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la primera vez con KIVA.
texts.en:
Tomas and his wife produce milk which they sell to one of the collection companies from the city of La Paz. He lives in his own house in the community of Irama Belén in the municipality of Achacachi, two and a half hours' journey from the city of la Paz. They have two children who are school age. Tomas has a few heads of cattle which provide him with milk.

He needs the loan to buy a dairy cow so he can increase his milk production and his income for the family.

Tomas's dream is to increase his number of animals, increasing the milk production in his community. This is the first time he has asked for a loan with IMPRO and the first time with Kiva.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow to increase his volume of milk production in order to improve his income.

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in western Kenya and is famous for its rainforest. Many farmers in the area grow maize, sugar cane and bananas, with maize being the primary crop. The density of the old growth trees in the Kakamega forest, and the variety of crops grown in the area, make this an excellent area for beekeeping. 

Aggrey is married and has four children. His wife works as a businesslady, while he farms their land. He has been farming for seventeen years and is currently growing maize, vegetable and fruits. Aggrey is excited to become a beekeeper because “I love honey as medicine and it has a good income.”

This is Aggrey’s first loan with Kiva and he plans to use the income from his beehives to buy even more hives and invest in beekeeping. Aggrey’s dream is to “own a big farm and do more farming.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production

loans.name: Avec-Mali

texts.en: Watch a video to learn more about AVEC-Mali! AVEC-Mali is a women’s association based in Mopti, Mali with 74 members. The association engages in a variety of activities, such as selling clean cookstoves, teaching women to read and write and educating women about family planning. In July, nine women from the association starting selling solar lamps (seven of them are featured in the photo). As of the end of September they sold 1,200 lamps and they have ambitious plans to grow the sales. Korotoumou (fourth from the left) is one of nine members of AVEC-Mali who sell solar lamps. She is 47 years old and has six children. In addition to her work with the women’s association, Korotoumou is the matron at a health center in Mopti, and she sells grains. In July, she started selling solar lamps to fisherman, students and farmers, who are reliant on kerosene and flashlights for light. With a solar lamp, her customers can save money. Kerosene and mobile phone charging currently cost about $110 per year; whereas, a solar lamp costs $25 and has a lifetime of about five years. These solar lamps provide 8 hours of light and can charge a mobile phone. On top of being less expensive, solar lamps are more durable and reliable and keep people from stealing mobile phones. “With a solar lamp, you don’t have to go to a mobile phone charging station and give your phone to someone who may steal your phone or use the call credit you have on your phone,” says Korotoumou. Selling solar lamps provides income for the women and for the association. The women earn $2 for every lamp they sell and the association earns $3. The money the association earns is invested in a warehouse to store solar lamp inventory and motorcycles to distribute the products. The solar saleswomen are well organized – each responsible for her own sales territory. They educate their communities about the benefits of solar lights and generate lamp sales through group meetings and demonstrations at night. Since customers cannot afford to pay for the lamps up front, the women need working capital. A Kiva loan will allow the solar saleswomen to obtain solar lamp inventory from NOTS Lampe Solaire on credit. When they receive payment from their customers they will re-pay the Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy solar lamps that they will sell in their communities

loans.name: Yolbin

texts.es: Gracias por apoyar a Yolbin, quien con su credikiva compró mucha mercancia, especialmente ropa y calzado, que llegó promovida por su catalogo. Con su credikiva, pudo obtener un mayor capital de trabajo, y vendió mediante la forma  pre-pago. Su negocio ahora posee mas clientes y ella logró ampliar el tiempo que da a su clientela para pagar; hoy posee mas ingresos, para continuar mejorando su calidad de vida. En la actualidad Yolbin está aplicando a un credikiva, mediante el cual comprará ropa, encargada y cumplirá con la solicitud de la temporada, que usualmente impacta positivamente sus ventas, haciendo de su  credikiva una inversón exitosa.  Ella dice a sus finaciadores: " Doy Gracias por los beneficios brindados, el crédito ha sido pieza fundacmental para mejorara mi calidad de vida".
texts.en:
Thank you for supporting Yolbin, who used her Kiva loan to buy a lot of merchandise, especially clothing and footwear, which was promoted via her catalogue. With her Kiva loan she was able to have a larger working capital and sold via the pre-payment method. Her business now has more customers and she was able to extend the time she gives her customers to pay. Now she has a better income, so she can carry on improving her quality of life.

Currently Yolbin is asking for a Kiva loan which she will use to buy clothing which has been ordered and will be able to meet the seasonal orders. These normally impact positively on her sales, making her Kiva loan a successful investment. She says to her lenders:" Thank you for providing these benefits, the loan has been the essential key to improving my quality of life".

loans.use: to buy stock which has been ordered.

loans.name: Farida

texts.ru: Фарида кредитуется в ИМОНе повторно. Она честная и трудолюбивая женщина. Фариде 25 лет. Она разведена и сама воспитывает свою дочь. Она уже несколько лет занимается собственным бизнесом. Она занимается купле продажей молочных продуктов. Фарида покупает молоко, кефир с других районов оптом и реализует в розницу на местном рынке. Фарида является основной кормилицей семьи. Ее мать занимается предоставлением услуги швеи, а отец является сварщиком. Фарида хочет увеличить свой оборотный капитал таким образом получить больше дохода. Она хочет, чтобы ее сын вырос в достатке и получил хорошее образование. Она запрашивает займ на сумму 3000 сомони для покупки молочных продуктов. Она ждет вашу доброту и надеется на ваше милосердие.
texts.en: Farida is taking out a loan at IMON for the second time. She is an honest and hard working woman. She is 25 years old. She is divorced and is raising a daughter by herself. Farida has been doing own business for several years. She buys and sells dairy products. Farida buys milk and buttermilk from other regions in wholesale and sells it in retail at her local market. Farida is the main provider in the family. Her mother provides sewing services and her father is a welder. Farida wants to increase her working capital and by that get more profit. She wants for her daughter to grow up in prosperity and get a good education. She is asking for a loan in the amount of 3,000 somoni to buy dairy products. She is waiting for your generosity and hopes for your kindness.

loans.use: to buy dairy products to increase working capital.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.ru: Ахмаду 53 года, женат и имеет пятерых детей. Он является мастером на все руки. Ахмад одновременно занимается животноводством, растениеводством, садоводством и понемногу делает ремонты в своем районе Хуросон. Ахмад сейчас в хозяйстве имеет 3 барашек и одну корову. Все его деятельности, кроме животноводства являются сезонными. Поэтому Ахмад просит кредит, чтобы купить пару барашек, и увеличить поголовье скота. У него 20-летний опыт в этой сфере деятельности и с животными он справляется на отлично.
texts.en: Ahmad is 53 years old, married and has five children. He is a good handyman. Ahmad does animal husbandry, field crop cultivation, horticulture and sometimes also does repairs in his region of Khuroson. Right now Ahmad has three sheep and one cow. All of his businesses besides livestock are seasonal. This is why Ahmad is asking for a loan to buy some sheep to increase the headcount of livestock. He has a twenty year experience in this field does a great job at keeping livestock.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Baban

texts.en:
Baban is a 25-years-old single man. He lives with his parents and he has an internet cafe that provides internet services. He had to drop out from school for a while to work and help his family. Finally, he managed to finish high school and run his internet cafe. With the income from his internet cafe and this loan, Baban can now continue his information technology studies at college.
Every year Baban faces the problem of making ends meet at the beginning of the school year when the additional expenses that is needed to cover college fees are due. With this loan, he can now accommodate these expenses.
He is requesting a loan to pay for his college tuition fees. Baban plans to finish university education and to use this experience in his business.
The story of Baban is just one of the many examples of Izdiharona for economic development clients that are able to get better education.

loans.use: to pay for his college tuition.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 39-year-old Martha from Kandehtown Bo. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 5 years and 18 years. One of her children is currently attending school. She began this business because she wanted to help her husband educate their children. Martha runs a general stock business where she sells soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets. She has been running this business for 10 years. She works at the business throughout the week for 10 hours per day. Martha says that her business is doing well.
Martha has requested a loan in order to purchase soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets for resale. The extra income from this loan will allow her to pay her children's school fees and increase her business. In the future, Martha plans to expand her enterprise even more. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase soft drinks, bread, biscuits and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Liliy

texts.en:
Lily is 27 years old and single with one child. She runs a beauty salon, and she has been in this business for three years with a monthly income from the business of KES 89,140. She is borrowing a loan of KES 100,000, which she intends to use to purchase business assets especially salon electronics especially  driers and blow driers. This will ensure efficiency by eliminating salon queue and ascertaining quick services.

Lily plans to expand her salon even further with more assets with the anticipated profits. This is her third loan and her hope and dream is to have a self-sustaining business.

loans.use: To purchase business assets especially salon electronics like driers and blowdriers

loans.name: 12 De Junio Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “12 DE JUNIO” iniciará el tercer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Senkata, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Dora es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de ropa, venta de abarrotes, tejido de mantas, venta de juguetes, taller de carpintería, venta de zapatos.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Dora es integrante, ella indica que hace tres años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una asesora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de taller de costura de ropa; da a conocer que este negocio fue heredado por sus padres hace varios años atrás, es por ello que ella sigue el negocio.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de tela) que adquirirá de las tiendas mayoristas de la ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente a  la elaboración lo comercializará en otros departamentos de Bolivia. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener a su familia, ya que ella es soltera y tiene tres hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta los consultorios de salud que se tiene en la oficina.
texts.en:
Communal bank “12 de junio” is in its third cycle with Pro Mujer, in the satellite office of Senkata. It is composed of eight members and run by a board where Dora is the president. The members have different activities, such as selling clothes, selling groceries, weaving blankets, selling toys, carpentry and selling shoes.

This loan will be beneficial for small micro entrepreneurs such as Dora. She has been working with Pro Mujer for three years, invited by a representative from the institution that paid her a visit. She has a tailor’s shop, inherited from her parents some years ago.

The loan she is requesting will help her to increase her working capital. She will buy fabrics from the different wholesalers in the city of El Alto. She will make clothes and sell them in different regions in Bolivia. With this activity, she can maintain her family. She is single and has three children.

When asked what she likes the most about Pro Mujer, she says she likes the healthcare facilities.

loans.use: to buy fabrics.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en: Emma is 39 years old and lives in Gardnerville, Liberia, which is one of the most populated area in the Montserrado County. Emma is married with four children between the ages of 8 years and 21 years, whom are in school and live at home. For ten years now, she has been selling used clothes in the community market. Emma started this business with the little amount she could afford and she learned this trade from her friends. She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. She hopes to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Dorise

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 33 -year-old Dorise from Kandehtown Bo, Southern area in Freetown. She is married with 3 children between the ages of 5 years and 12 years.Two of her children are attending school. Dorise runs a cookery business; she sells cooked rice, fried fish and cool drinks. She has been running this business for the past 8 years. She wakes up at 4:30am to prepare her cookery business and she will not rest until the food is finished. One of her daughters usually helps her to run this cookery business. Her business is her only source of income. Dorise finds her major hardship as sometimes preparing the cooked food is very difficult. Dorise has requested a loan in order to purchase cooking items including bags of rice, coconut oil and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to change her cookery structure and pay her childrens school fees. In the future, she plans to have her own residence. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking items including bags of rice, coconut oil and pure water.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman aged 39 years old with five children all attending different schools. She lives in a rural setting with her family and her two nephews who lost their parents. She is the one who caters for their school fees. Mary is a farmer who deals in agriculture, where she grows passion fruits and tomatoes. She works six days in a week and each day, she works for eight hours. She also trades passion fruits as her side source of income. She started her business in 1990. Mary started this business in order to increase her family's income and she has acquired this loan to pay the school fees for her children. She said that she sells her products to traders from Kampala. Her future dream is to educate all her children to higher levels of education. Her biggest challenge is the unpredictable weather changes, for example, prolonged drought and at times too much rain. She describes herself as a hard working woman and she encourages lenders to continue helping farmers.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Dara

texts.en: Dara is a resident living in the Ponhea Leue district, Kandal province. She is 28 years old and married with a small child, who is attending local primary school at a low grade. She has a store in the village selling different kinds of beverages, including soft drinks and alcoholic drinks. She has run this business for almost one year now, and earns enough to provide for her family’s daily food. Dara is very thankful for the financial assistance extended to her in the previous loan cycle as she was able to improve her business and better her living conditions. She would like to apply for another 700 US dollars loan to increase her stock of beverages for a constant sale. She hopes that, through this loan, her sales will result in better profits. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and help her child in his education’s needs.

loans.use: to increase her stock of beverages for a constant sale.

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is married, with six children and they are all in school.She sells charcoal on a retail basis. She takes care of an additional family member (mother). She has been in this business for three years. She works six days a week. She gets additional income from selling chapatti and fried cassava. 

Sauda has applied for a loan of UGX 700,000 (Uganda shillings) from Micro Credit for Development and Transformation SACCO (MCDT SACCO) to buy more bags of charcoal. Her major business challenges include seasonality (rainy season), which hinders her movements, and transportation. 

She aspires to get a van for transporting her charcoal and to build rental houses. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Nadzua

texts.en:
Nadzua is a potential maize seller who has been in the business for some time. She sells maize grains to earn a living out of the profits.
The previous loan helped her buy more maize grains for sale. Here again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy 6 sacks of maize grains for sale.

She appreciates for the support granted.

loans.use: to buy 6 sacks of maize grains for sale.

loans.name: Torees Group

texts.en: Catherine, who is in her late 30s, is a single woman with a son who is in school. Since 1998, Catherine has been running a tailoring business. She is doing great in her business and starts working from 8.00 am to 6.00 pm each working day, and is able to make a good profit. This will be her sixth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used her previous loans to start a shop selling tailoring materials as well as buying one tailoring machine and more tailoring materials. Catherine managed to pay back all her previous loans successfully. She used her business profits to cover school fees and her household expenses. Catherine will use this new loan to buy additional tailoring materials. She dreams of opening a tailoring school. Catherine will share this loan with her loan  group "TOREES", which has a total of 3members. The members of this group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy additional tailoring materials.

loans.name: Bintu

texts.en: Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 40-year-old Bintu from Torpoi town Bo, Southern area in Freetown. She is married with 5 children, between the ages of 1 year and 20 years. Four of her children are attending school. Bintu runs a fast food business - she sells gari salad, fried fish and cool drinks. She has been running this business for 10 years now. She starts preparing the food from 8:00am and she will not rest until the food is finished. Her business is her only source of income. Bintu describes her major hardship as business being difficult sometimes. Bintu has requested a loan in order to purchase cooking items including bags of gari, coconut oil and pure water. The extra income from this loan will allow her to improve her living conditions and pay her children's school fees. In the future, she plans to further expand her business. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to purchase cooking items including bags of gari, coconut oil and pure water.

loans.name: Salomie J.

texts.en: Salomie J. is 44 years old, married and lives at in Gardnerville of Montserrado County which is the commercial city of Liberia. She lives with her five children, who are aged between 20 and 30 years old, and whom are in school. She ended her education at the 8th grade. For the past five years, Salomie has been running a table market where she sells shortbread and soft drinks near the local market. She started this business with her husband's savings. She likes the way her customers buy from her and the profits she generates per day. Salomie is requesting a loan to purchase more flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and soft drinks for her business. In the near future, she wants to build a shop.

loans.use: to purchase more flour, sugar, butter, eggs, and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, soda, local gin, and spirits for her pub.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is 42 years old and lives in the town of Bungokho in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has 6 children, who are all currently in school. For the past 5 years, Lydia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, where she sells sugar, soap and salt. To help expand her business, Lydia has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food items for sale in her shop, thus helping Lydia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her shop's business. Lydia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lydia, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more food items for sale in her shop

loans.name: Mayimuna

texts.en: Mayimuna is widowed with seven children, six of whom go to school. She has no additional family members. She sells second hand shoes at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for two years. She works seven days a week.  She has applied for a loan of Uganda shillings 300,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy bales of second hand shoes.  She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. Her major business challenges include seasonality (rainy season), which hinders her movements, and transportation. She aspires to become a wholesaler and have a permanent business premise.  She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bales of used shoes

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet is a single mother of three children and two of her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members (her mother). She has a business of selling used clothes and has been in this business for 5 years. She has applied for a loan of 400,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bales of used clothes. She doesn’t have any other income-generating activity. She works at the market seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and thieves. She is aspiring to become a wholesaler and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and not to piped water.  Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is married with five children, and three of her children go to school. She operates a pub on a retail basis. She takes care of additional family members(cousin). She has been in this business for 6 year. She works six days a week.

She has applied for a loan of Uganda Shillings 700,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more crates of beer, soda, and local brew. Her major business challenges include seasonality and electricity.

She aspires to own a fully stocked pub and get a permanent business premises. She resides in her own house, and the family has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses include bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer, soda, and local brew.

loans.name: Rufiji Group

texts.en:
Zaituni, who is in her late 30s, is married with six children who are still going to school. She has been running several businesses selling soft drinks and fruits and vegetables for one year now. She works from 7:00 am to 10:00 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

This will be Zaituni's 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase the soft drinks, fruits and vegetables and to start selling dry fish. She has paid back all of her loans successfully.  She used the profits to pay school fees and household expenses. She will use this to buy more dry fish to resell.  She dreams of building her own house.

Zaituni will share this loan with her loan group "RUFIJI", which consists of 16 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more soft drinks, fruits, vegetables and to start selling fish.

loans.name: Lan

texts.en:
Lan is a homemaker who manages the household tasks in the Ruessei Keo district, Phnom Penh. She is 33 years old and married with three children. She has a life partner with her husband, aged 35, who is a Tuk Tuk driver, earning an income around USD11 per day. Most of the income in Lan’s family comes from her husband providing transportation-based services, but it is not always a stable source of income. 

Currently, the motorcycle he uses for serving his customers is old and breaks too often, which is the reason that pushes her to take out a loan for the purpose of buying a good quality motorcycle for her husband. This will help Lan’s family to live a simple lifestyle and sustain their current business.

loans.use: to buy a good quality motorcycle for her husband's Tuk Tuk service.

loans.name: Gocha

texts.en:
Gocha, 50, is married and lives with his wife and two underaged children in the Ozurgeti district. Gocha runs his own trading business in his district. Specifically, he owns a store in the fair market where secondhand clothing and shoes are sold. Gocha also has a grocery store in the neighboring village and sells various groceries. He has been in the trading business for ten years and is very skillful in this field. He works hard all day long and his projects are profitable, which is why he’s decided to start another grocery store in his district, near the open market. The location is great, as it is always crowded, and according Gocha’s estimates it will be lucrative. 

With a loan of 4,100 USD Gocha will purchase a stock of basic groceries to start a store. He will hire the salesperson and generate additional income for his family's well-being. With determination and his loan, he expects to improve his income and give his family members what they need.

loans.use: to start up a grocery store.

loans.name: Jesca

texts.en:
Jesca is 38 years old and lives in the town of Soroti in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has six children, who are all currently in school. For the past five years, Jesca has been working hard to manage her wholesale and retail shop, which sells sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand her business, Jesca has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential items for the shop to sell, and will help Jesca to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. She hopes that in the future she will be able to increase the business. 

Jesca is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jesca who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase for more essential items for the shop to sell.

loans.name: Ani

texts.en:
Ani is from Vanadzor town, where she lives with her husband and two-year-old daughter. She has been re-selling clothing for two years already. Ani purchases clothing from the city market and resells it to the neighboring villages. The income that she gathers from this business helps her to cover the family's daily costs. By applying for this loan, Ani asks for financial support to be able to purchase new stock of clothing to sell to customers.

She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. The loan is very important for Ani, and she hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for new stock of clothing to sell to customers.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
31-year-old Annie is single and has three children aged between 8 and 12. They are currently attending school and living at home. She did not go to school, but she runs her shop business very well. With the loan proceeds she will buy more tissue, soap, soft drinks, toothpaste, etc. for her business. She said aside from fewer goods in her shop, she does not have any problem with her business. With a little money from her mother, she managed to establish this business 11 years ago. She learned this trade from other businesswomen. She enjoys the flow of her customers and their fast buying. 

Her dreams are to move from a small shop to store business and live a better life in the future.

loans.use: to buy more tissue, soap, soft drinks, toothpaste, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Aminadab

texts.en:
Aminadab is 34 years old. He is married with four children. He would like to use this Kiva loan to cover labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. He wishes to invest profits from his farming in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and cover labor costs during maize production

loans.name: Awad

texts.en: Mr. Awad is 46-years-old and works as a security guard at night. During the day he is a rice grower. He has an extended family with five children, two daughters-in-law and two grandchildren. They all live together in the parental house. With the support of Seva MFI, Mr. Awad started agriculture in 2011. With the profits of the last years, he has bought a second hand tractor and extended his home. His goal is to plant more rice areas to have more income and take better care of his family. He needs a new loan of SRD 12,000 to purchase inputs for the rice production.

loans.use: To purchase diesel and seeds for his rice production.

loans.name: Rawin

texts.en: Mr. Rawin is 30-years-old and lives with his parents. He is recently married. Rawin works together with his father in their fields. In 2009, he has taken a loan from Seva MFI and bought a truck to work on his own and for other farmers. He repaid this loan on time and now he wants to do rice cultivation on his own and needs a new loan of SRD 12,000 to purchase fertilizer and pesticides. In the future he wants to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides for his rice cultivation.

loans.name: Raj

texts.en: Mr. Raj is 52-years-old and lives with his mother. He is a rice farmer from an early age and he has inherited agricultural land from his parents. With the support of families from the Netherlands, he bought his tractor. Mr. Raj was previously financing his input by rice millers, who normally charge high interest rates and offer low prices. Since 2008, Seva MFI has financed his inputs, which resulted in more income and savings. With the savings, he has renovated his house and revamped his tractor. He asks for a new loan of SRD 7,500 to expand his rice production.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides for his rice cultivation.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a  Kiva borrower. He describes himself to be determined. He operates a retail store where he sells tomatoes. He describes his family challenge as lack of enough storage facilities. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy a water storage facility that will benefit four family members.They will be able to store sufficient clean water for domestic use. He hopes that in future he will sustain his family economically. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy a water storage facility.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin is 32 years old. He is married with two children. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase production. With profits from his farming, he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Buluhan

texts.en:
Buluhan is 33 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Buluhan has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells items like sugar, soap and salt. 

To help expand his business, Buluhan has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential items such as sugar, milk and bread for sale and will help Buluhan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Buluhan hopes that in the future he will be able to stock more goods for the shop to sell. 

Buluhan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Buluhan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.


"


"

loans.use: to buy more essential items such as sugar, milk and bread for sale.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en:
Horn, aged 55, is a fisherman working along the Tonle Sap River and also a farmer, growing rice and lotus. He has been operating in these businesses for nearly 23 years, making an income approximately USD 8.00 per day, which he uses for daily food and other home expenses. He is married and a loving father of three children, two of whom are still depend on his current income. 

As it is his second loan cycle, Horn will use it to invest into both farming and fishing business. He will buy fertilizers and seeds to apply to his crops. And he will also purchase fishing nets and gasoline for his boat. He is expecting a boost in his earnings and dreams of expanding his family-owned businesses. He is very thankful to lenders for financial support.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and seeds to apply to his crops.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a Kiva borrower. She describes herself as an ever happy person.

She has taken a loan of KES 41,500 to buy a water tank of 6,000 litres to store clean water for her tenants. They face a challenge of lack of water to clean toilets and for domestic use. She will be able to store clean water for her 50 tenants to use. She also does poultry farming to earn an extra income. She hopes that in the future she will own a pick-up to supply poultry produce.

loans.use: to buy a water tank of 6,000 litres.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    BENKADI est constitué de 5 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de36 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies dans le quartier  NIEBALA de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 2éme prêt. Le précédent prêt  à été correctement remboursé. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  condiments à l’image de BALAKISSA qui est la femme du milieu  dans la photo. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 2 cartons de cubes de diverses qualités avec les grossistes de Bamako. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The BENKADI group consists of five married women who average 36 years of age and four children each. They live in extended traditional families in the district of NIEBALA, city of Bougouni. They know one another as neighbors and friends, and through their business activities. They joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to strengthen their working capital and better conduct their activities. This is their 2nd loan cycle with the MFI. The first loan was correctly repaid. 

These women sell condiments. BALAKISSA, in the center of the photo, plans to use her loan to buy 2 cartons of various bouillon cubes from the Bamako wholesalers. She conducts her sales at retail, from her home and at the market, cash or credit, to a clientele consisting essentially of women. 

She expects to earn an average monthly profit of 15,000FCFA, which she will use to repay her loan and to invest in her activity.

loans.use: to buy condiments for sale.

loans.name: Saramaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    SARAMAYA est constitué de 4 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs maris, coépouses,  et enfants dans le quartier  HEREMAKONO NORD de la ville de Bougouni. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 1ér prêt.Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  condiments à l’image de AISSATA qui est la 2 eme femme assise dans la photo de la gauche vers la droite. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, diverses quantités de condiments   avec les grossistes de Bougouni. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en:
The Saramaya Group is made up of 4 women with an average age of 26 years and an average of 3 children.  They all live in traditional, extended families with their husbands, other wives and children, in the Heremakono Nord area of the town of Bougouni.  They know one another through friendship, business and local ties.  

In order to strengthen their financial situation and grow their businesses, the women work with the field partner, Soro Yiriwaso.  This will be their first loan with this field partner.  

The women of the group all run businesses buying and selling spices, seasonings and ingredients, as does Aissata (second from the left in the photo).  Aissata will use her loan to buy various quantities of spices, seasonings and ingredients, from wholesalers in Bougouni.  She sells her products from home and at the market.  Her customers are usually women and she sells for cash or credit.  Aissata expects to earn a monthly average of 40,000 francs CFA which she will use to repay the loan and invest in her business.

loans.use: to buy spices, seasonings and ingredients.

loans.name: Luz De Fe Group

texts.es: El grupo lo conforman cuatro socios de negocio uno de ellos es Isabel mujer de 35 años de edad, casada, su negocio es la compra y venta de cosecha desde hace 4 años, el crédito lo está solicitando para  la compra de cosecha de tamarindo. Jannette mujer de 48 años de edad su negocio es la compra y venta de cosechas desde hace 26 años, Yovanelia tiene la edad de 21 años su negocio es la venta de ropa nueva desde hace 6 años y Juan tiene 34 años su negocio es la compra y venta de cosecha desde hace 20 años.
texts.en: The group is comprised of four associated entrepreneurs, one of them is Isabel, who is 35 and married. She buys and sells different types of produce, whole harvests at a time, and has been doing so for 4 years. She asks for this loan in order to buy tamarind. The other members of the group are Jannette, 48, who has engaged in the same trade as Isabel for 26 years, Yovanella, 21, who has sold new clothing for 6 years, and Juan, 34, who has been in the produce trade for 20 years.

loans.use: to buy tamarind.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a single mother aged thirty six years old. She has two children one of whom who attends school. Margaret lives in Kyotera and she deals in a electronics business where she sells televisions, DVDs, woofers, radios, and many other electrical materials. She works 6 days per week and 14 hours per day. She said that she started her business in 2005. She also has rentals which supplement her family income.

Margaret started her business to earn a living and improve on the standard of living of her family. She has acquired this loan to add stock in her electrical business. Her clients are residents of Kyotera and traders from areas around Kyotera. Her future dream is to expand her business up to the level of wholesale. She faces the problem of high government taxes and lack of enough capital. She describes herself as a hard-working woman. She encourages lenders to reduce on the interest rates so as to enable even low income earners to have access to loans.

loans.use: to buy stock of electricals to sell in her business.

loans.name: Dancille

texts.en:
Dancille is 49 years old. She and her husband have been maize farmers for the past 18 years. Dancille would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. She needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase their production. With profits from her farming, Dancille wishes to invest in her business so that in the future she can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance her farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: to buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Ananias

texts.en:
Ananias is 56. He would like to use a Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Sahr

texts.en:
Pictured above is Sahr, a small-scale businessman base in Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. Sahr has come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of 5,000,000 Sierra Leon leones to boost the quality and size of his business.
 
Sahr is a native of Koidu city. The 52-year-old has been a businessman for 23 years now. He is currently selling electrical equipment/goods such as torch lights. 

The husband and father of five primary and secondary school-going pupils will use this loan in order to expand his business both in size and quality by buying a larger quality of electrical goods to add to his current stock.

loans.use: to buy a larger quality of electrical goods to add to his current stock.

loans.name: Irène's Group

texts.fr: C'est un groupe composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Irène (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 38 ans. Irène n'a pas fréquenté l’école. Irène est mariée à un certain Inoussa. Le couple a un enfant, qui n'est pas encore scolarisé. Irène vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Irène prépare du "Akpan (bouillie faite à base d'amidon de maïs, du sucre et du lait) à son domicile. Irène s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, et de fidéliser sa clientèle, Irène s’associe aux autres membres de son groupe pour solliciter un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le prêt antérieur a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: This is a group of three women who all live in the same neighbourhood.  The group representative is Irène (she has her hand raised in the photo).  Irène is 38 years old and did not attend school.  She is married to Inoussa and they live with their only child, who does not yet attend school.  In order to contribute to the expenses of their household, Irène prepares and sells "Akpan", corn patties that are dipped in sauce.  She buys her supplies at a market in Bénin.  This will be the second loan for Irène and the other members of her group.  They have requested this loan from the field partner, Alidé, to strengthen their businesses and retain their customers.  Their previous loan has been fully repaid.

loans.use: to buy maize, milk and sugar.

loans.name: Mayela Guisel

texts.es: Mayela mujer luchadora y emprendedora tiene la edad de 29 años, casada, con dos hijos bajo su cargo, su negocio es la venta de ropa usada desde hace 4 meses, ella solicita el crédito para la compra de ropa escogida por docena como pantalones de damas, de niños y de varón, camisas, camisetas, blusas, vestidos, toallas de baño, shores, etc.
texts.en: Mayela, a hard-working woman, full of fighting spirit, is 29 and married. She has two children to raise. Four months ago, she started her own business selling used clothing. She asks for this loan in order to buy clothes she chooses by the dozen such as trousers (ladies', men's, and children's), shirts, T-shirts, blouses, dresses, bath towels, shorts, etc.

loans.use: to buy used clothing to sell.

loans.name: Recheal

texts.en:
Recheal is 50 years old and lives at Paynesville North which has the larger local market in Montserrado. She is a 4th grade dropout. She is married and her husband is not working. They have two children ages 4 and 21, only one who is in school and lives at home. 

Recheal described herself as a hardworking woman. Over the past ten years, she has been selling charcoal in the local market. She likes her business because of the ways customers respond to it. She started this business with money given to her by mother. She uses a bus to get her goods to her shop. She is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal for her business. She plans to expand her business. She says thanks to the lenders who continue to support BRAC Liberia to enable small business people to increase their business volume.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Alfredo

texts.en:
Alfredo has been engaged in a hog-raising business for more than ten years. He is 61 years old, married and blessed with four grown children. He is full of hopes in life.

Alfredo's wife owns a retail store and engages in a transportation business. The couple has been working hard to improve his hog raising and the retail store to make them productive and profitable.

To make his goal realistic, he is seeking a loan of PHP 30,000, allowing him to buy hog feed and vitamins. He knows that this additional capital will help to  make his hogs healthier upon reaching their optimum growth and enable him to get a greater price. He is hoping for approval of his requested loan amount.

loans.use: to buy hog feed and vitamins for his hogs.

loans.name: Jean

texts.en:
Jean is 51 years old. He is a father of five children. He has been in the farming business for the past 15 years. 

He would like to use the Kiva loan to support labor costs and buy fertilizers during maize production. He needs to buy fertilizer in order to increase his production. With profits from his farming he wishes to invest in his business so that in the future he can acquire machines and tractors that will enhance his farming capacity. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizers and support labor costs during maize production.

loans.name: Gregoria

texts.es:
Gregoria es productora de leche la cual vende a una de las empresas recolectoras de leche en la ciudad de La Paz; Gregoria  vive en casa propia, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos, los cuales están en edad escolar, en la comunidad Tipampa del municipio de Achacachi, a dos horas  de viaje de la ciudad de La Paz, cuenta con cuatro cabezas de ganado  las cuales le proporcionan leche, que es el producto que le produce ingresos para mantener a su familia.

El crédito lo requiere para compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar su producción lechera y sus ingresos para su familia.

El sueño de Gregoria es incrementar sus cabezas de ganado, aumentando la producción  de leche en su comunidad.
Es la primera vez que solicita crédito junto a IMPRO y la primera vez con KIVA.
